reviewText:
A light hearted wonderful game with a great sense of humour.

McPixel is a fast paced indie game that stars “McPixel” a strange character that goes around saving the day from all things explosive!
You are thrown into various different situations in various different settings and given 20 seconds to save the day, how that turns out is down to you and your fast thinking. It is not at all a serious game and it’s very likely that 95% of the time you will blow something up on your first try. But it’s still fun none the less and the level comes back around faster than you can even think about it. It has a somewhat crude but hilarious sense of humour, with very bizarre gags in each stage.
There was quite a few times during my time playing that I just thought, “Who the hell would do that?” and had a little chuckle to myself.  But there you go, that is the magic and charm of McPixel.
The music is extremely repetitive, but strangely enough it isn’t annoying. It’s more catchy then annoying.
The main game is pretty short and there is a load of free DLC for you to play afterwards if you want to. (So there are a lot of days to save!)
If you were to play this nonstop the whole thing would probably take you a few hours, and it’s probably a good idea to take breaks due to its fast paced nature.

Generally I really enjoyed it; I thought it was pretty fun; there are a lot of references and things to have a laugh at in this game. So it’s something fun to throw on when you are bored.

reviewText:
MCPIXEL was shockingly enjoyable and entertaining. To break it down for you, its a point and click puzzle game set in brief different scenarios, such as in a falling elevator, you need to analyze how to save the day. You have  an emergency button, elevator buttons, an old man, a bell hop and an extinguisher. What do you do to save the day? These are wacky and weird situations, usually involving bombs or gasoline. None of which lasts no longer than 15 seconds. The game is broken up into 4 chapters, each chapter has 3 or so clusters of 6 scenarios / challenges. If you fail doing a challenge, you don't do it over and over until you get it right, you just go to the next uncompleted scenario.

I completed the entire first chapter in about 15 minutes, which is 18 challenges? There is free DLC, which is a series of selectable clusters made by fans or whomever. There is a lot of content here, but the real catch is the challenges just don't last a long time. They're pretty easy to figure out.

The cherry on top of this is that there are some laugh out loud results. Maybe the results are so LOL because they're so unexpectedly random. Again, I expected nothing from this game and got a lot of entertainment from it. I'll be returning to the game to see the other quirky scenarios with crude graphics.

The strangest thing is that it works quite well either as a good bad game or just as a clever indie puzzle– with an excellent length/price ratio thanks to the continuous release of free new levels.

Long version:McPixel is the kind of game that you can hardly place anywhere. Still, despite the complete absence of logic, it works surprisingly well as a puzzle game, and the incentives to find all possible solutions can open up a few clever visual gags that really show how great imagination the creator has. reviewText:
What happens when you combine MacGyver, point and click, and fast paced insane logic? Well, you get McPixel, a game that isn’t afraid to throw logic out the window and give some straightforward jokes.

McPixel is a game that can be described as “WarioWare meets point and click adventure”. Each scene has a 20 second timer, with McPixel trying to save the day, often by disarming a bomb. Actions range from moving, picking up objects, and interacting with objects. Given the short time limit to solve the situation, players will tend to combine as many objects as possible. The game’s crazy logic behind the puzzles don’t tend to make sense and often the solutions are found by trial and error, though there are some more sane solutions that can be found. Solving each scene is simple, but the gameplay assists in something bigger, which is the game content itself.

In this game, McPixel must save the day. How he does so depends on the scene and the criteria for doing so is often stretched. Throughout the game, various gags are presented, often with random and crazy ideas. Often some gross out humor is applied, so be aware of the random jokes and occasional bodily functions. Along with these kinds of gags, many pop culture references are in the game, especially with TV and video games. These references I feel tend to work better at giving a good laugh, though the various random occurrences that don’t reference anything also are worth a laugh. Anyway, the bulk of the game is in its humor, and McPixel has no shortage of comedy to toss around and make you laugh.

On a short note, the game applies a retro style with its art and music. The game is pixelated like an old game, though McPixel does employ a consistent and certain character style. Scenery tends to be pixel art as well, or in some cases pixelated versions of photographs. Animations are crucial to delivering the game’s gags, and the crazy qualities of them work fine with the retro style. Music is the same way as well, using some chiptunes for some nice fat beats. There are not many songs and the tracks are quite short, but it does achieve the retro style with some neat chiptunes.

McPixel is a game for those looking to laugh at the absurd and crazy situations and interactions. Gameplay is kept simple to focus on delivering comedy, though the game’s crazy logic can make some puzzles confusing and require trial and error. Still, with some retro styling with the art and music mimicking old video games, McPixel makes for a game to laugh at some silly things.

reviewText:
In my 17 years of gaming, never have I come across a game that is so bad. It is basically a point and click game. The aim of the game is to locate and destroy/get rid of a bomb by clicking on objects on the screen. There are several stages which each has several levels.

The good points are that you get lots of levels (100) which you can happily sink alot of time in.


Now for the bad points. First off, although the game tries to be humorous by having you embarass or do terrible things to the characters in the game, some of the actions that the main character does may be offend/disturb people (e.g. peeing on an alien). Second is that when you start the game there is literally no tutorial which was somewhat frustrating trying to figure out what to do. Third issue is that when you fail to locate the bomb, you will proceed to the next level. The game then goes through all five levels of the stage untill you have disarmed the bomb in each stage. This forces you to remember exactly which items not to click on, but the main problem is that it is somewhat difficult to find which items can be interacted with. Fourth issue is that the game is extremely repetitive. Once you finished the first level, all the other levels are exactly the same except with new scenery. Fifth issue is that the music is really annoying as it plays 1 track for the ENTIRE game.

If you like point and click games, avoid this game. If you like a fun and enjoyable games, avoid this game. It isn't even worth $1 let alone $5.

reviewText:
McPixel, the king of gag games. A parody, unto a parody of a parody in a parodying universe. Parodyception ladies and gentlemen.

McPixel is a very simple premise, find a way to stop a bomb from blowing up in less than twenty seconds. Sometimes it's easy, requiring one or two steps, but sometimes you'll wrack your brain trying to figure out what the hell to do.

The controls are point and click, no ifs ands or buts. I took this game down in little over two hours play-time on my tablet, and have since not touched it (with good reason). After beating all the levels, finding all the gags, and playing the bonus levels, there really isn't much to do, unless you're into custom player levels.

All the gags are cheesy, including having McPixel kick people, or ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on something, humping a PS3... you get the idea. Honestly, while I got a laugh out of a few of them, most of the gags made me want to gag.

All in all, if you need to pass time, get this on Play Store, the App Store, or any mobile device, but not here. Play it though, at least once.

For the steam sale price, it's definitely worth picking up.

Incredibly stupid gameplay mixed with incredible stupid puzzle solutions - you've got the best puzzle game of 2013!
McPixel is a fast paced humorous mini-puzzle game, where our main hero McPixel (an obvious reference to Macgyver) tries in 20 seconds to defuse a bomb and save the day. Everything is controlled with one mouse button and that's where it's charm lies. To use or pick up an item you just press it. And hope for the best. Sometimes pressing something (or someone) will pick that thing or even a person up to use with other items. In other cases, pressing will lead to McPixel kicking the said item or person. Usually that kick will result in everything blowing up.
Sometimes the solution is to press on the fire to take your pants off and take a ♥♥♥♥, saving everyone's life. Pressing the fire in the next puzzle will make McPixel jump to the fire, combusting himself. In the third puzzle, pressing the bomb will make McPixel kick it, destroying half the city. The solutions range from simply press the fire extinguisher to extinguish bomb to kick a fat naked guy in the showers, so that he would slip on the soap and land on a bomb, defusing it.
Every single solutions is stupid, yet brilliant at the same time.
It also offers FREE DLC, a thing that you wouldn't get in a 60$ realistic millitary shooter". And for a such a minimal price

reviewText:
McPixel is a point and click game adventure game.  Although enjoying very few point-and-click games, I was willing to give a chance to.  In the end, I did not find myself having a fun experience.

The game is meant to be a comedy of sorts, having both slapstick and crass humor.  Although some of the gags are good, the logic behind solving the puzzles is convoluted and confusing, sometimes having no logic at all.  This results in you usually having to just use trial and error over and over to figure out the right order of operations to solve a level.  This is made somewhat less annoying, however, as the load times between failed attempts is very quick.  In my opinion, the gameplay would better fit a more narrative driven game than a rapid-paced puzzle game.

The other problem I had with the game was the music.  Throughout the entire game, only one very repetitive music track is used.  At least as far as I got, there is no sound effects, ambient noises, voice acting, etc.  This means the one looping music track is the only thing you will hear throughout the entire session.

Although I did not find the game fun, players who enjoy rage games" would probably get a few good laughs out of the game.  I would recommend waiting for a sale however
date: as there is not much gameplay for a $5.00
recommended: compared to other games on Steam for the same (or lower) price."

reviewText:
I remember playing this as a Flash game long ago. The retail version is basically the same with more levels. It's a very Warioware-like game. Every stage you get around 30 seconds to save the day (often by stopping a bomb explosion). While the odds of beating a stage the first time are low, there's usually less than 10 permutations you can do on any given stage, so you'll figure it out quickly.

Similar to Wizorb, perhaps its best feature is how inexpensive it is - under $1 on a sale. Even less than that if it's in a bundle.

If you decide to play and don't feel like reading instructions, just don't forget that SPACE lets you skip just about all animations/intros. It will make your gameplay experience a hundred times better.

I finished most of the content, including seeing most of the gags, in about 3 hours. It was.. somewhat fun, I guess. Might have been better left as a Flash game. Still, I'll give it a 6.5 out of 10. Still recommended, but just barely, and only on a sale or in a bundle. Also, if it matters to you, this game has Steam cards.

reviewText: There is always some level of arbitrariness in a point & click.  Logically there might be a dozen ways to make a guard leave his post or to interact with a pump, but only one will be correct because of the artificial nature of the game.  A good point and click will keep this under control with reasonable puzzle solutions, while rewarding the player for their time and effort with humor, good music, an interesting story or other unique charm.  McPixel does none of this.  The music is short, repetitive, and not at all pleasing to listen to.  The puzzle solutions are arbitrary enough that all you can really do is click whatever is in the level until you manage to click the correct objects in the correct order.  It lacks a cohesive narrative.  There is humor, but it is crass and juvenile; even compared to other crass, juvenile humor, McPixel is in the back of the pack.\n\nThere is no reason to buy this game at any price.  There will always be something better to spend your money on.

reviewText:
How do I start??

This game is probably the strangest thing that I have ever experienced.  It's a game that makes you feel smart for making decisions you would only think are logical if your having a bad trip.  but anyway gameplay.

This game is a fast pased point and click puzzle/problem solving game.  you have 20 seconds to figure solve the puzzle and/or (and I hope your not reading this in an airport) find the bomb.  The crazy and over the top solutions are fun to discover, but get old quick, and can feel like punishment for thinking logically.  Each episode like thing, has 6 stages that you must complete, and if you do fail one, you still get to try again once you've played every other stage in the cycle so it is at least easy for how ubsurd and difficult it is to beat each stage.

This game has a few good features to keep you entertained for a while.  The story mode is split into 4 chapters, each with 3 episodes, with 6 stages inside, which equals to 60 stages, nothing special, but with the amount of content inside some of those stages, there has been some hard work and thinking done.  You also unlock little mini-games as you beat each chapter.  They aren't anything note worthy, but that is a problem with this game.  It's to chaotic and crazy to remember any given part.  Finally there is endless mode, where you can play through each stage from the game, in one giant episode (not a great completion bonus but it's the best it's got).

WARNING: Spoilers(?) ahead?
The only real thing that comes close to a story, is a cutscene that is unlocked once you beat the last chapter.  It has McPixel... I don't even really know what happens.

For how odd this game is, I enjoyed myself when playing it, but that doesn't excuse the parts of it that are bad (which is sadly a lot).  But seeing as this game did show some good at points, I think that I can safely call it the BEST WORST game ever.
So my rating for this game, is a VERY generis 4/10

reviewText:
Personal Rating: 2 of 10

You play a hero named McPixel where your ultimate goal is to save the world (I think). Sounds interesting? Guess again. Each stage has like a few scenarios where you need to randomly click on the screen to complete a series of action. The puzzle is completely nonsensical and logic does no apply in the solution. There are a couple of actions and reactions in 1 scenario but only 1 action works. Even if you successfully complete a scenario, you are still required to try out all possible actions in order to score a gold. When you play, you can select the stage but not the scenarios in the stage. You are only given a couple of second to perform 1 complete possible action with 1 outcome before the game automatically switches to the next scenarion. It will repeat itself until you complete all the scenarions before you can replay the stage again to get gold.

The sound and music system in this game is repetitive and dull. After a while, it really got to my nerve and I decide to play the game in silence.

Personally I think this game fits to be a easter egg in bigger games like GTA or Saints Row where you can engage an arcade machine to play.

Oh and if you are looking to collect the cards, they do drop but at a much slower rate. My first card drop was at the hour mark (approximately there). My total play time includes a couple of minutes fiddling the game and the remaining was to collect cards.

The only thing I liked about this game is that you can change your pixel display style which I think its quite artistic in a way.
